title: Understanding Money and the Role of Banking

slides.title: What is Money? Defining its Characteristics
content: Money: Anything portable, divisible, durable, and stable that serves as a medium of exchange.
Portability is crucial for ease of transactions in everyday business. Try bartering with grain.
Divisibility: Facilitates transactions of various scales; can be easily subdivided (dollars to cents).
Durability: Money needs to withstand wear and tear to maintain its integrity; paper vs. eggs.
Stability: Value needs to be steady to ensure trust in business and exchanges; hyperinflation vs Gold
slides.script: Welcome to our discussion on 'Understanding Money and the Role of Banking'. To start, what exactly *is* money?  It's not just wealth. This slide outlines four key characteristics: portability, divisibility, durability, and stability.  Think about what makes something a good form of money: easy to carry, able to be broken down into smaller units, long-lasting, and relatively consistent in value.

slides.title: Money's Multifaceted Roles in Economic Systems
content: Money as a Medium of Exchange: Simplifies transactions; eliminates barter (a double coincidence of wants).
Money as a Store of Value: Enables saving for future purchases, holding its worth over time.
Money as a Measure of Worth: Common basis to assess relative values of different products/services.
Money should have all three characteristics to work in a monetary system effectively.
slides.script: Money also performs crucial functions in a modern economy. As a medium of exchange, it eliminates the inefficiencies of bartering.  It acts as a store of value, allowing us to save for the future.  Finally, it serves as a measure of worth, providing a standard unit for pricing goods and services. A good money should have all three roles to function effectively.

slides.title: Deciphering M-1: A Core Component of the Money Supply
content: M-1: The most liquid (spendable) forms of money.
Paper Money and Metal Coins: Currency (cash) issued by the government.
Checks: Orders instructing a bank to pay a sum to a payee from your funds.
Checking Accounts: Demand deposits where funds may be withdrawn.
Checking accounts are easily accessable for transactions in business.
slides.script: Let's break down M-1. This represents the most liquid part of the money supply – what's readily available for spending.  This includes physical cash – paper money and coins – as well as funds in checking accounts that can be accessed on demand, often via checks.

slides.title: M-2: Expanding the Scope of the Money Supply
content: M-2: A broader measure of the money supply, more than M-1.
Time Deposits: CDs held for a fixed term with penalties for early withdrawal. (<100k)
Money Market Mutual Funds: Short-term, low-risk securities shared by investors.
Savings Accounts: Readily available for transactions but less liquid than cash or checks.
M-2 has a greater volume than M-1
slides.script: Now, let’s look at M-2. This includes everything in M-1, plus other forms of money that are a little less liquid, but still easily convertible to cash.  This consists primarily of time deposits like certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds, and savings accounts, all under $100,000.

slides.title: The U.S. Financial System: A Network of Institutions
content: Financial Institutions: Facilitate the flow of money from savers to borrowers.
Commercial Banks: Accept deposits, make loans, earn profits; interest and dividends.
Savings Institutions: Accept deposits, make mortgages, offer checking services.
Credit Unions: Non-profit, cooperative institutions promoting thrift and reasonable rates.
Non-Deposit Institutions: Take in money, provide interest or other services, make loans. (pension funds, insurance companies...)
slides.script: Now, let's talk about the backbone of our financial system – the financial institutions.  These entities facilitate the flow of money between those who have it (savers) and those who need it (borrowers).  We'll touch upon several key types including commercial banks, savings institutions, credit unions, and nondepository institutions like insurance companies.

slides.title: How Financial Institutions Create Money
content: Banks expand the money supply by making loans from deposits.
Fractional Reserve Banking: Banks are only required to keep a fraction of deposits on hand.
Excess Reserves: Funds available for lending after meeting reserve requirements.
The money multiplier effect multiplies the original deposit throughout the economy.
slides.script: Financial institutions, in particular banks, play a crucial role in money creation.  They operate on a fractional reserve system, meaning they only need to keep a small percentage of their deposits on hand, lending out the rest.  This lending activity multiplies the initial deposit throughout the economy. The money multiplier affect emphasizes that the banks don't loan 1:1 funds deposited from one source.

slides.title: The Federal Reserve System: Structure
content: Created by Congress in 1913, the nation’s central bank.
Board of Governors: Appointed by the president to oversee the Fed's activities.
Reserve Banks: 12 regional banks that hold reserves and set discount rates.
Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC): Monetary policy to manage the money supply.
Member Banks: Nationally chartered commercial banks and some state ones.
slides.script: At the heart of the US financial system is the Federal Reserve, commonly called 'The Fed'. It's the nation's central bank, designed to regulate the financial system and control the money supply. Its structure includes a Board of Governors, 12 regional Reserve Banks, and the powerful Federal Open Market Committee, which is responsible for setting monetary policy.

slides.title: The Functions of the Federal Reserve (The Fed)
content: Government's Bank: Holds government accounts, manages nation's currency.
Bankers' Bank: Provides loans and storage for commercial banks.
Check Clearing: Facilitates payment transfers.
Regulates commercial banks and its activities. (The Federal Reserve Act)
slides.script: The Fed plays several critical roles.  It acts as the government's bank, managing its accounts and currency. It also serves as the bankers' bank, lending money to commercial banks. Furthermore, the fed oversees a check-clearing process that ensure funds are transferred from one bank to another smoothly.

slides.title: The Fed's Monetary Policy Tools: Steering the Economy
content: Monetary Policy: Management of the nation’s economic growth.
Money Supply and Interest Rates: How the Fed influences economic activity.
Reserve Requirement: Percentage of deposits that banks must hold.
Discount Rate: Interest rate at which banks can borrow money from the Fed.
Open Market Operations: Fed's sale and purchase of securities in the open market.
slides.script: The Fed wields significant influence over the economy through monetary policy. It manages the money supply and interest rates.  Tools at its disposal include adjusting reserve requirements for banks, setting the discount rate at which banks can borrow from the Fed, and conducting open market operations – buying and selling government securities.

slides.title: Forces of Change: Government, Tech, & Anti-Terrorism
content: Government Intervention: Actions to stabilize a struggling financial system.
Anti-Crime Regulations: Measures to deter criminal misuse of the financial system, including tracking illicit transactions.
Electronic Technologies: Digital payment and transfers and other new advancements.
Government Intervention is an attempt to return to equilibrium after a downturn. (2008)
Electronic payments, online Banking and “Plastic money”.
slides.script: Finally, the money and banking system is in constant evolution. This slide highlights three key drivers of change: government intervention aimed at stabilizing the financial system, anti-crime and anti-terrorism regulations to prevent the misuse of funds, and finally, the ongoing impact of electronic technologies like online payment systems.
